intro: Placus clarkei, commonly known as the Clarke's plume, is a rare and delicate flowering plant native to specific regions of South Africa. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads composed of both ray and disk florets. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils and thrives in full sun, showcasing its adaptability to arid conditions. Its striking, feathery inflorescence adds ornamental value, making it a sought-after species in botanical gardens. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Placus clarkei is considered vulnerable to environmental changes and habitat loss.
